persona.name: Asha Okoye

occupation.title: Preschool child / Dependent
occupation.organization: Private family household with periodic attendance at a neighborhood community preschool
occupation.description: Asha is economically inactive and dependent. Her 'daily work' is playing, learning basic social skills and routines, and receiving care from her parents, grandparents and a hired helper (when available). Responsibilities appropriate for her age include tidying up toys after play if reminded, helping to hand small items to adults, and following simple hygiene routines (washing hands before meals, putting shoes on with help). She participates in short group play sessions at preschool where she practices taking turns, circle time, singing, finger painting, and simple counting. Caregivers emphasize bilingual exposure (English plus a regional language such as Igbo and some Nigerian Pidgin); she is learning to use a shared smartphone for video calls to relatives and for watching nursery videos under supervision.

persona.residence: Lagos, Nigeria (urban neighborhood, apartment in a mixed residential/commercial area)
persona.education: No formal education yet; attends a local community preschool/kindergarten two mornings a week (informal, play-based). At home she is exposed to storytelling, alphabet songs, counting games and occasional rote learning from older relatives. Caregivers have taught her basic shapes, colours and letters through play but she has not completed primary school.
long_term_goals: To grow up in a safe home where she can play freely and be close to her family.
To learn to read and write in English and in her family's regional language(s).
To be able to visit both her parents' families for festivals and celebrations and feel welcome in both places.
To make lots of friends at school and have a small group of playmates she trusts.
To be able to say longer stories and sing songs in front of a small audience without getting shy.
To be healthy and active — able to run, climb and dance without frequent illness.
To keep and cherish her favorite doll and toys as she grows older.
To learn how to count money and help with small tasks around the house like tidying toys.
To attend a proper school (primary) nearby and to like going there.
To keep the family tradition of celebrating both sides (religious and cultural) as she grows older.
persona.style: A lively, expressive urban child with a mixed-language cadence. Speaks in short sentences, often mixing Nigerian English, Pidgin and a regional language (some Igbo words and phrases). Her voice is high and singsong when excited. She uses gestures to emphasise points, points to objects rather than always naming them, and often clasps a comfort object (a small cloth or soft doll). Mannerisms include tilting her head when curious, tucking hair behind her ear when concentrating, bouncing lightly when impatient, and using exaggerated facial expressions to make a point. She mimics adults' speech rhythms and laughs with a throaty giggle. In public, she is cautious with strangers but will warm up quickly if given an object to hold or a game to play. She prefers routines and is comforted by repetition (same bedtime story, same lullaby). Her speech registers switch from baby-talk (with family) to clearer preschool phrases with older children and teachers. When upset she stamps her foot or throws short, explosive tantrums, but usually calms if picked up, sung to, or offered a small snack.

traits: Curious — constantly explores corners of the apartment, inspects bags, peeks into kitchen cupboards when allowed.
Affectionate — hugs adults, leans into caregivers when sitting, likes to hold hands while walking.
Playful — invents simple games, loves imaginative play (pretend cooking, dolls' tea parties).
Sensitive — easily upset by loud arguments, sudden changes of plans, or being ignored.
Sociable with familiar people — laughs and chats with cousins, teachers and regular neighbors.
Wary of strangers — may cling to caregiver or hide behind a leg for the first few minutes.
Stubborn — insists on doing some tasks herself (putting on shoes, holding a spoon) even when clumsy.
Imaginative — creates stories about animals, believes toys have feelings, and animates everyday objects.
Observant — notices small changes (a new shirt on a parent, the absence of a household helper) and reacts.
Quick to forgive — after brief tantrums or hurt feelings she returns to play with little lingering grudge.
Attention-seeking — will perform simple songs or dances to gain adult approval.
Routine-oriented — finds comfort in predictable meal times and a consistent bedtime ritual.
Empathic — comforts other children who cry, offering a toy or patting their back.
Play leader — when with peers she sometimes organizes games and roles, but can also insist on her own rules.
Experimentative — tastes small bits of food, tries stacking objects higher than she should.
Modest resilience — recovers from falls quickly if helped emotionally by an adult.
Selective sharing — will share favored items occasionally but may refuse with strong attachment objects.
Vocal expressiveness — uses a wide range of vocal tones to communicate moods (whispering, squealing).
Rule-aware — repeats rules told by adults and tries to enforce them in play.
Attachment-oriented — strongest emotional bond is with her primary caregiver (mother), followed by grandmother.

big_five.openness: Medium-High. Enjoys novelty (new toys, songs), shows active imagination and curiosity for stories and make-believe.
big_five.conscientiousness: Low-Medium. Shows some ability to follow simple routines and instructions but has limited impulse control typical for age.
big_five.extraversion: Medium-High. Energetic and sociable with familiar people, enjoys group play and singing; can be shy initially around strangers.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Generally warm, helpful to other children, quick to comfort peers, cooperative with familiar adults.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium. Prone to short, intense emotional reactions (tantrums, clinginess) but recovers relatively quickly with comfort.

interests: Dolls (a small cloth doll named 'Nene') — likes to tuck the doll into tiny blankets and feed it with a toy spoon.
Toy kitchen play — imitates cooking, stirring with a wooden spoon, arranging plastic fruit and cups.
Singing and nursery rhymes — especially local lullabies and English nursery songs (twinkle twinkle, 'A B C').
Bubbles — fascinated by blowing and chasing bubbles in the courtyard.
Storytime — simple picture books with animals, repetitive phrases and bright illustrations.
Stacking and sorting games — enjoys stacking cups and matching colours.
Crayons and finger paints — likes bright colours and smearing paint with fingers rather than brushes.
Simple puzzles — 4–6 piece puzzles with animals or vehicles.
Running and climbing on safe playground equipment — loves slides more than swings.
Pretend phone calls — mimics adults making calls, holds a small toy phone to her ear.
Listening to her grandmother’s stories about festivals — sits very still during certain traditional tales.
Dressing up — putting on a scarf or cap and pretending to be an adult or a superhero.
Watching short educational videos on a shared smartphone (under supervision) — enjoys dancing clips.
Eating snacks with a crunchy texture — likes puffed snacks and plantain chips.
Playing with toy cars/mini buses — lining them up and making driving sounds.
Hide-and-seek — enthusiastic participant, often giggles loudly while hiding.
Pretend school — mimics being a student, copying teacher phrases learned at preschool.
Water play — splashing at a shallow basin in warm weather with plastic cups and toys.
Collecting small objects — bottle caps, bright wrappers and smooth stones found in the courtyard.
Imitating animal sounds — especially goats, chickens and cats.
likes: Sweet, mildly spiced porridge (e.g., pap/akamu) with a touch of sugar.
Soft, warm blankets and the texture of cotton.
Bright patterned clothes (floral, polka dots) and colourful hair beads.
Hands-on play that allows her to be messy.
Short walks to visit a nearby fruit seller — loves to look at mangoes and oranges.
Bedtime stories in both English and the family's regional language.
Being carried on a caregiver's back or hip when tired.
A consistent morning song used by her mother to wake her up.
Simple picture books with tactile elements (flaps, textured patches).
Attention and praise for small tasks ('Good girl!' makes her beam).
Sweets only occasionally; she enjoys dates and ripe banana the most among fruits.
Stickers as rewards — she treasures colourful animal stickers.
Warm baths with a small plastic cup and soap bubbles.
Dancing when an upbeat song is played on a phone or radio.
Pretending to feed adults and dolls as part of role-play.
Being involved in simple household rituals like sweeping with a small broom.
Quiet corner with cushions for listening to stories.
Watching family members prepare festive meals; fascinated by the spices and colours.
Car rides that include safe songs and counting street lights.
Holding hands and walking with her mother in crowded places.
dislikes: Long periods of separation from primary caregiver; cries when left abruptly.
Loud, sudden noises such as thunder or construction drilling.
Bitter or very spicy foods — tends to spit them out and refuse.
Crowded bus rides that jostle her — prefers space to move safely.
Being forced to share a favourite toy immediately — will resist strongly.
Dirty, sticky hands without a chance to wash — protests loudly.
Tickles that go too far — will yell 'Stop!' if overwhelmed.
Getting water in her face during baths — dislikes sudden splashes.
Medical needles and injections — becomes anxious in clinics.
Being dressed in oversized, itchy clothing — fusses until changed.
Having her nap missed — becomes irritable and weepy.
When older children snatch toys — responds with crying or pushing.
Having her hair brushed roughly — prefers gentle touch and songs during grooming.
Vegetables with bitter taste (bitter leaves) — usually refuses without sweetening.
Sour fruits when not fully ripe (e.g., unripe tamarind).
Long waits at markets — becomes bored and restless.
Adults who use a harsh tone when correcting her — withdraws or hides.
Being woken abruptly from deep sleep — disoriented and tearful.
Brushing teeth if done too roughly or with unfamiliar toothpaste flavour.
Rainstorms when she cannot go out to play.

beliefs: Elders know best — she internalizes that grandparents' advice is important and often repeats their phrases.
Family is the centre of safety — home and nearby relatives are trusted sources of care.
Certain objects (her doll, blanket) bring comfort and 'good luck' during sleep.
Stories told by her grandmother about ancestors and festivals are true and special.
There is a spiritual presence at festivals — lights, songs and prayers matter.
Sharing sometimes is required, but certain toys are 'mine' and that's acceptable to adults for young children.
Being polite (saying 'please' and 'thank you' in both languages) is praised and will bring positive attention.
If you cry loudly enough an adult will come — crying is a way to signal urgent needs.
Bravery is expected in small doses (standing on a low step, trying new foods) but fear is acceptable.
Teachers at preschool are helpers and should be listened to, even if they are strict.
Food offered by elders is usually safe and should be tasted when asked.
Bathing is part of the daily cleanliness ritual and helps keep sickness away.
Some days are special (birthdays, religious days) and are for eating sweets and wearing nicer clothes.
Singing and dancing are good ways to celebrate and solve sadness.
Some places (a particular room, a relative's house) are associated with particular feelings — comfort, excitement or boredom.
Money is an adult thing; coins and notes are interesting objects but adults manage them.
Phones are for seeing relatives who live far away; hearing a distant voice is magical.
Healthcare workers are helpers but the clinic can be scary because of needles.
If she behaves well she'll receive small rewards (stickers, sweets) — tangible incentives are part of discipline.
Strangers might be kind but one must be careful and stay near a caregiver in public places.
Washing hands before eating keeps germs away — she accepts this as a rule taught by caregivers.
Certain animals (chickens, goats) are useful and familiar; they make predictable sounds that have meaning.
Night is a time for safety and bedtime routines; lights and lullabies mark the end of the day.
It is normal to eat different foods on festival days (special stews, sweet snacks) — food signals celebration.
Delaying gratification is taught in small ways (waiting for her turn to have sweets).
Saying sorry is important when someone gets hurt — adults expect apologies in small disputes.
Family rituals (crossing oneself or saying a short prayer) are calming and protective.
Being curious is rewarded with stories and encouragement to explore safely.
Adults sometimes make mistakes, but they protect and love children — forgiveness is modeled.
The city has both safe and unsafe spots; the caregiver determines where it's okay to play.
Clean clothes and neatly combed hair are signs that a day is special and worth attention.
Relatives who live far away are still 'close' because they call, send pictures and gifts.
skills: Basic spoken vocabulary of several hundred words across English, Nigerian Pidgin and some Igbo phrases (e.g., 'nne' for mother, simple greetings).
Can form short sentences (3–6 words), ask simple questions ('Where?', 'Why?') and label familiar objects.
Fine motor skills adequate for age: can hold crayons, scribble, stack 6–8 blocks, and fit simple puzzle pieces.
Gross motor skills: runs, climbs low playground structures, jumps in place and throws a small ball awkwardly.
Basic self-care with help: can attempt to feed herself with a spoon, remove shoes, and wash hands with guidance.
Emerging toilet training — mostly daytime dry but occasional accidents happen.
Social turn-taking for short cycles: understands 'your turn' and 'my turn' in simple games after prompting.
Recognizes colours (red, blue, yellow, green) and common shapes (circle, square, triangle).
Counts reliably to 10 and can enumerate 11–20 inconsistently; understands 'one more' and 'all gone'.
Memory for routines: remembers where favourite toys are kept and follows a 4–5 step bedtime routine.
Can imitate adult tasks in play (sweeping, placing plates) and copy simple rhymes after hearing them once or twice.
Comfort with basic technology: can tap a touchscreen to play a nursery video and recognizes camera for video calls.
Simple problem-solving: will try multiple ways to reach a toy (move a stool, ask for help) and adapt when blocked.
Basic emotional regulation skills developing: uses a comfort object, seeks out caregiver for reassurance.
Language imitation — able to copy tunes and short phrases learned from relatives and media.

general: Uses a handful of gestures (pointing, waving, blowing kisses) to supplement limited vocabulary.
Mimics adult domestic chores during play — sweeping, pretending to wash plates and stirring an imaginary pot.
Has short, intense tantrums when tired, hungry or denied a favored object; resolves quickly when soothed.
Frequently touches fabrics and textures — fascinated by soft, fuzzy and shiny surfaces.
Repeats favourite phrases or parts of songs repeatedly until satisfied.
Insists on small rituals before bed (a particular story, a kiss on the forehead, a soft doll placed next to her).
Seeks physical closeness when tired — climbs into caregiver's lap for reading or napping.
Greets familiar neighbors with a wave or a shy 'hello' and often blows kisses to known faces.
Uses pretend play to process events (acts out a market visit with toy food after a trip to the market).
Organizes toys by colour or type during play time, sometimes narrating actions out loud.

morning: Wakes between 6:30 and 7:30 AM, often to a mother's soft song and gentle cuddling.
Has a simple breakfast (porridge or bread with fruit), washes hands with help and dresses with adult assistance.
Plays quietly for 20–45 minutes with stacking cups or dolls while caregivers prepare for the day.
Occasionally attends community preschool two mornings a week where she participates in circle time and songs.
midday: Active playtime in courtyard or small playground after morning activities; enjoys supervised interaction with neighborhood children.
Has a mid-morning snack (fruit, puffed cereal) and a small lunch prepared by family (stewed yam, rice with mild sauce).
Short nap after lunch — usually 1 to 1.5 hours depending on activity level and prior sleep quality.
afternoon: Quiet play or storytime after nap; sometimes watches a short educational video on a shared phone.
Helps a caregiver in small ways (carrying a basket of toy dishes), practices basic counting games.
Visits grandparents or nearby relatives a few times a week where she receives additional affection and alternate language exposure.
evening: Family dinner around 6–7 PM with a mix of family cuisines; participates in simple table rituals and is praised for trying new foods.
Bath time and teeth cleaning followed by a consistent bedtime routine: a short story in English and regional language, a lullaby, and lights out by 8 PM.
If overstimulated she may require extra calming (soft singing, quiet cuddle) before sleep.
weekend: Visits extended family for festivals or market trips, attends small family gatherings, and plays with cousins.
Longer outdoor play sessions and occasional visits to a more distant relative or place of worship with the family.
Participates in small ceremonies (naming event remembrances, birthday celebrations) and enjoys being the centre of attention.

health.general: Overall healthy child with normal development for age. No chronic medical conditions. Growth and immunizations tracked by local clinic.
medical_history: Full-term birth with normal delivery; no NICU stay.
Up-to-date on routine national immunizations (BCG, polio, DPT, measles) per caregiver report and clinic card.
Common childhood illnesses: 2–3 mild upper respiratory infections and one bout of diarrhoea in the past year, all resolved with outpatient care and home fluids.
No diagnosed developmental disorders; early childhood screenings by preschool and clinic show milestone attainment within typical ranges.
Underwent one outpatient clinic visit for a minor ear infection which resolved with antibiotics.
health.nutrition: Mixed diet with staple family foods; somewhat picky but generally receives adequate calories. Occasional supplement of vitamin syrup recommended by clinic.
health.sleep: Usually sleeps 10–12 hours per 24-hour period (including a daytime nap). Bedtime routine is consistent and promotes good sleep hygiene but disruptions occur during family travel.
health.dental: Brushing started but not always consistent; has some plaque buildup noted at last clinic; caregiver advised on better brushing routine.
health.mental_health: Displays age-appropriate attachment behaviours and transient separation anxiety; temperamentally sensitive but soothed by caregivers. No persistent signs of developmental trauma or anxiety.

relationships.name: Chinelo (mother)
relationships.details: Mid-20s, Igbo heritage, works intermittently selling prepared foods from home and sometimes manages a small stall. Attentive, sings to Asha often, the primary decision-maker for daily care. Speaks Igbo and English at home.

relationships.name: Raj (father)
relationships.details: Early 30s, of South Asian heritage (Indian origin), works in a small electronics repair shop in the neighborhood. Spends evenings and weekends at home. Gentle with Asha, teaches her simple English nursery rhymes and counts objects in both English and a few Hindi words. Maintains contact with his extended family via phone calls and occasional small gifts.

relationships.name: Mama Obi (grandmother)
relationships.details: Lives nearby and visits daily. Primary source of traditional stories, songs and festival knowledge. Helps with feeding, bathing and keeps a close eye on Asha's behaviour and routine.

relationships.name: Uncle Emeka
relationships.details: Young adult relative who plays rough games, takes Asha to the corner shop for sweets sometimes, and teaches her to mimic animal sounds. Present at family celebrations and a source of boisterous play.

relationships.name: Amaka and Ife (cousins/peers)
relationships.details: Children aged 3 and 5 who live in adjacent apartments; play daily in the courtyard and sometimes attend preschool with Asha. They share toys and engage in short cooperative games.

relationships.name: Adaora (preschool teacher)
relationships.details: Early childhood educator at the community preschool who runs circle-time activities, songs and simple drawing. Encourages sharing and basic numeracy.

relationships.name: Neighbour Mrs. Yusuf
relationships.details: Older neighbor who often bakes small snacks for children and babysits occasionally; speaks kindly and has a soft spot for Asha.

relationships.name: Community helper ('Titi')
relationships.details: A hired helper who assists mornings and afternoons when both parents are busy; responsible for preparing snacks and supervising play.

other_facts: Born in a small urban hospital in Lagos; birth certificate registered within weeks of birth.
Given her first name 'Asha' by her father inspired by a Hindi word meaning 'hope' — family story often recited at gatherings.
Surname 'Okoye' comes from her mother's Igbo family and ties her to a large extended family network in the city.
Family household mixes culinary traditions: porridge and plantain on some days, mild curry-based stews on others.
Home sometimes experiences intermittent electricity and relies on a small generator for evening lights during long outages.
Household has one shared smartphone used for occasional video calls with relatives abroad and for showing short nursery videos to Asha.
Asha's first word reported by family was 'mama' followed soon by 'ball' and 'dada' (father).
She learned to walk between 11–13 months and was an early climber on low furniture.
First attended a naming ceremony with both families present when she was a few months old; that memory is retold often and tied to dress-up photos she enjoys looking at.
Family celebrates both Christian-style and Hindu-influenced festivities in a blended manner — she has been present at small prayer gatherings and has seen varied rituals.
Asha once had a minor burn from touching a warm pot; caregivers now supervise more actively near the stove.
She has a small scar on her knee from a fall at age 2 during playground play — everyone jokes about it as a 'brave' story.
Her favourite outfit is a bright yellow dress with small bird prints that she requests frequently.
The family apartment has colourful wall stickers of animals and counting charts placed at her eye level.
Grandmother keeps a small 'story box' with pebbles, cloth scraps and a single carved bead used to teach counting and memory games.
Asha has been filmed in a few short family videos dancing; these clips are shared among relatives and praised, boosting her attention-seeking performances.
When visiting markets she is fascinated by loudspeakers and will dance briefly when hearing music from a stall.
She once tried to give a stray kitten some of her snack — caregivers redirected the behaviour but kept the memory as an anecdote of her empathy.
Family documents important health visits in a small cardboard file kept on a shelf; Asha will often 'help' by handing it to an adult when asked.
She is mildly fearful of thunderstorms and will request a song and to be held until the storm passes.
A baby photo album is kept in the living room and Asha enjoys turning the pages and pointing at images of herself as a newborn.
Her father occasionally brings small toys from his work trade — tiny screwdrivers and plastic gears — which fascinate her and are used for pretend-play tools.
A recent visit to a children's play café (a short city excursion) left a strong positive impression; she remembers a particular foam slide and asks about it sometimes.
She participated in a small preschool 'show-and-tell' where she presented her doll and earned a sticker, boosting her confidence.
Family keeps a modest emergency fund in cash at home; adults often talk quietly about saving but shield her from financial worries.
Her mother has taught her a short phrase used as a safety rule when on walks: 'Hold my hand, please.' Asha repeats this to younger neighborhood toddlers.
Asha enjoys being part of small rituals such as washing hands together before eating; these are framed as precious family time.
During a week-long visit to maternal relatives she picked up a new song in Igbo and now sings a blend of languages in her rhymes.
She has a favorite sticker (a smiling sun) that she places on drawings and is visibly proud of when an adult notices.
When family members leave the apartment for long hours she waits by the door for their return and will run to greet them with open arms.
Asha once refused a new dish at a family gathering, causing a gentle familial negotiation involving coaxing, a story and finally a small reward when she tried a bite.
Her bedtime story routine includes a specific sequence (story, two-minute song, light turned off) — deviation from it can cause brief sleep resistance.
Family photos in the living room show multi-ethnic relatives; caregivers intentionally expose her to both cultural languages and celebrations to build identity comfort.
She learned to wave and say 'bye-bye' to taxi drivers and street vendors, which endears her to local sellers who often give small candies.

The household practices a mixture of disciplinary approaches: gentle explanation for small misbehaviour and time-limited removal of privileges for repeated dangerous actions (e.g., climbing furniture unsafely).
Her favourite time of the week is when grandparents visit and share small treats — these visits are associated with storytelling and extra physical affection.
Asha has a soft spot for yellow-coloured items and often selects yellow toys or clothes when given a choice.
Her father sometimes tells her about his childhood games in India, which she receives with wonder and often asks to hear the story again.
When upset by a minor scrape she prefers a sing-song approach to consolation; holding and singing works more effectively than stern talking.
The family is careful to expose her to multiple languages but uses code-switching thoughtfully so she can build functional bilingual skills without confusion.
Nearby community playspaces are a regular part of her social life; she recognizes the faces of regular vendors and caregivers there and reacts with excitement upon arrival.
